reportSummary.summary: The Pickwick Reservoir Watershed Management Plan addresses water quality impairments in Yellow Creek, Indian Creek, Bear Creek, and their tributaries in northeast Mississippi. The plan seeks to reduce sediment, nitrogen, and phosphorus, restore aquatic habitats, and remove impaired stream segments from the 303(d) list through a wide suite of management practices, monitoring, and coordinated outreach over a three-year initial period.
organizations: Tishomingo County Soil and Water Conservation District
Alcorn County Soil and Water Conservation District
Mississippi Department of Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks
Mississippi Soil and Water Conservation Commission
Prentiss County Soil and Water Conservation District
reportSummary.geographicRegion: Northeast Mississippi (Tishomingo, Alcorn, and Prentiss Counties)

goals.description: Develop a mechanism for removing Caney, Bear, Cripple Deer, and Little Cripple Deer Creeks and Holly Branch from MDEQ’s list of impaired waters and return these streams to conditions needed to support the natural biological communities typical of this region.
goals.sourceExcerpt: The long-term goal ... is to develop a mechanism for removing Caney, Bear, Cripple Deer, and Little Cripple Deer Creeks and Holly Branch from MDEQ’s list of impaired waters and return these streams to conditions needed to support the natural biological communities typical of this region.

goals.description: Establish a locally-led watershed team to address water quality issues.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: Short-term goals to be achieved during the first three years ... Establishment of a locally-led watershed team to address water quality issues.

goals.description: Complete a Source Water Protection Plan for the Short Coleman Water Association.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: Completion of a Source Water Protection Plan for the Short Coleman Water Association.

goals.description: Document baseline conditions for sediment, nitrogen, and phosphorus loading in all listed stream segments.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: Documentation of baseline conditions for sediment, nitrogen and phosphorus loading in all listed stream segments.

goals.description: Reduce sediment, nitrogen, and phosphorus loads.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project (with targets determined as baseline data become available)
goals.sourceExcerpt: Reduction in sediment, nitrogen and phosphorus loads.*

goals.description: Improve water quality in Caney and Bear Creeks so that at least 40% of the stream lengths can be removed from the 303(d) list of impaired water bodies by 2015.
goals.sourceExcerpt: Improve water quality in Caney and Bear Creeks so that at least 40% of the stream lengths can be removed from the 303(d) list of impaired water bodies by 2015.

goals.description: Attain water quality standards in Indian Creek from the Iuka POTW outfall to Pickens Branch.
goals.sourceExcerpt: Attainment of water quality standards in Indian Creek from the Iuka POTW outfall to Pickens Branch.

goals.description: Restore at least 20 acres of riparian buffer, revegetate at least 10 miles of logging roads, and stabilize at least 1500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
goals.schedule: First three years of the project
goals.sourceExcerpt: Restoration of at least 20 acres of riparian buffer ... revegetation of at least 10 miles of logging roads ... stabilization of at least 1500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

bmps.name: Animal Exclusion
bmps.description: Install fencing to prevent animal access to stream banks and plant excluded lands in hardwood vegetation to provide a buffer.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Animal Exclusion – Cost-share assistance will be available to land owners who install fencing to prevent animal access to stream banks in listed portions of Bear, Cripple Deer and Little Cripple Deer Creeks, Holly Branch and all areas in the Yellow Creek watershed. Assistance will also be available to plant excluded lands in hardwood vegetation to provide a buffer for the adjacent stream bank.

bmps.name: Pasture Restoration
bmps.description: Restore overgrazed or poor-condition pastures, potentially converting to native warm-season grasses.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Pasture Restoration – Cost-share assistance will be available to land owners who wish to restore overgrazed pastures or pastures which have been identified as being in poor condition.

bmps.name: Rotational Grazing
bmps.description: Install fencing to divide pastures to enable rotational grazing and prevent overgrazing.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Rotational Grazing – Cost-share assistance will be available to land owners who install fencing to divide pastures so that rotational grazing can be used to prevent overgrazing and pasture degradation.

bmps.name: Grade Stabilization
bmps.description: Construct grade stabilization structures to reduce erosion in gullies, ditches and other drainages.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Grade Stabilization – Cost share assistance will be available to land owners to construct stabilization structures to reduce erosion in gullies, ditches and other drainages.

bmps.name: Sediment Basin
bmps.description: Construct settling basins, retention ponds or similar structures to reduce sediment run-off from agricultural lands.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Sediment Basin – Cost share assistance will be available to land owners to construct settling basins, retention ponds or similar structures to reduce sediment run-off from agricultural lands.

bmps.name: Harvest Planning
bmps.description: Develop harvest plans for landowners to outline BMPs for logging and minimize sedimentation.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Harvest Planning – Land owners wishing to receive funding assistance through this project will work with the Mississippi Forestry Commission to develop a harvest plan ... including proper Best Management Practices (BMPs)...

bmps.name: Logging Road Revegetation
bmps.description: Sow grasses along logging roads immediately after harvest and regrade to redirect runoff.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Logging Road Revegetation – Cost-share assistance will be available to sow grasses along logging roads immediately after harvest is complete.

bmps.name: Landing Restoration
bmps.description: Sow grasses on logging landings used to stage equipment.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Landing Restoration – Cost-share assistance will be available to sow grasses throughout areas used to stage equipment ...

bmps.name: Stream Crossing Restoration
bmps.description: Grade and reforest areas where logging stream crossings were required and stabilize streambanks.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Stream Crossing Restoration – Cost-share assistance will be available to grade and reforest any areas where stream crossings were required during harvest activities. If needed, funds will also be available to stabilize stream banks in these areas ...

bmps.name: Riparian Buffer Restoration
bmps.description: Restore at least 20 acres of riparian buffer in Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Restoration of at least 20 acres of riparian buffer in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

bmps.name: Logging Road Revegetation (quantified)
bmps.description: Revegetate at least 10 miles of logging roads in Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Revegetation of at least 10 miles of logging roads in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

bmps.name: Stream Bank Stabilization
bmps.description: Stabilize at least 1500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.
bmps.sourceExcerpt: Stabilization of at least 1500 feet of severely eroding stream bank in the Bear and Yellow Creek Watersheds.

implementation.description: Seek grant funds to assist land owners with BMP installation.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Seek grant funds to assist land owners with BMP installation May 2006 May 2008 MSWCC, MFC, TVA

implementation.description: Provide a Watershed Coordinator for project oversight.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Provide a Watershed Coordinator for project oversight March 2008 End of project SWCD

implementation.description: Solicit land owner participation in cost share programs.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Solicit land owner participation in cost share programs June 2008 August 2011 SWCD, MFC

implementation.description: Develop demonstration sites to increase public awareness/involvement.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Develop demonstration sites to increase public awareness/involvement June 2008 June 2009 TVA, SWCD, MFC

implementation.description: Host site tour to highlight BMPs and watershed activities.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Host site tour to highlight BMPs and watershed activities June 2009 End of project TVA, SWCD, MFC

implementation.description: Develop Source Water Assessment for Short Coleman Water Association.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Develop Source Water Assessment for Short Coleman Water Association June 2008 June 2009 TVA

implementation.description: Develop Source Water Protection Plan for Short Coleman Water Association.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Develop Source Water Protection Plan for Short Coleman Water Association July 2009 March 2010 MDEQ, EPA, TVA

implementation.description: Conduct educational events for public awareness and participation.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Conduct educational events for public awareness and participation September 2008 End of project TVA, EPA

implementation.description: Establish BMPs on lands throughout the watershed to reduce pollution loading.
implementation.sourceExcerpt: Establish BMPs on lands throughout the watershed to reduce pollution loading June 2008 End of project SWCD, MFC

monitoring.method: MBISQ standard protocols or TVA Level II protocols; joint sampling with MDEQ/TVA
monitoring.frequency: Twice every five years (initial, then after three years, then two more years)
locations: Caney Creek at Mississippi Highway 365
Little Yellow Creek at Mississippi Highway 365
Bear Creek at Mississippi Highway 30
Bear Creek at County Road 86
Cripple Deer Creek at County Road 157
Cripple Deer Creek at AL/MS state line
Holly Branch at County Road 85
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Biological monitoring during this project will consist of benthic macroinvertebrates, fish and bacteriological collections.

monitoring.frequency: Every five years (initial, then five years later)
locations: TVA routine locations in Bear Creek and Yellow Creek watersheds
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Fish data will be collected every five years. Initial data ... and additional data ... in five years.

monitoring.method: Water sampling, laboratory analysis following quality protocols
monitoring.frequency: Monthly at all sites, plus storm event sampling at selected BMP locations
locations: Choate Creek at CR 260
Coke Creek at CR 944
Caney Creek at MS Hwy 365
Caney Creek at CR 300
Little Yellow Creek at MS Hwy 365
Little Yellow Creek at mouth
Bear Creek at MS Hwy 30
Bear Creek at Natchez Trace Parkway
Bear Creek at CR 86
Bear Creek at CR 68
Cripple Deer Creek at MS Hwy 25
Cripple Deer Creek at CR 157
Cripple Deer Creek at AL/MS state line
Little Cripple Deer Creek at CR 957
Holly Branch at CR 85
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Measurements of total suspended solids (TSS) and turbidity will be used to tract reductions in sediment loading in these streams.

monitoring.frequency: Monthly at all sites, plus storm event sampling at selected BMP locations
locations: Same as for TSS (see above locations)
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Measurements of total suspended solids (TSS) and turbidity will be used to tract reductions in sediment loading in these streams.

monitoring.method: In-situ measurements before 10:00 a.m. during summer months
locations: Same as for TSS (see above locations)
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Measurements of dissolved oxygen (DO) and biological oxygen demand (BOD) will be used to tract conditions.

locations: Same as for TSS (see above locations)
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Measurements of dissolved oxygen (DO) and biological oxygen demand (BOD) will be used to tract conditions.

locations: Same as for TSS (see above locations)
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Nitrogen (TKN, NO2-NO3 and NH3-N) and Phosphorus (TP) levels will also be monitored.

locations: Same as for TSS (see above locations)
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Nitrogen (TKN, NO2-NO3 and NH3-N) and Phosphorus (TP) levels will also be monitored.

locations: Same as for TSS (see above locations)
monitoring.sourceExcerpt: Since most devices used to measure DO also contain temperature, pH and conductivity capabilities, these parameters will also be measured.

outreach.description: Host public forums to increase awareness among local citizens and share project information; update meetings throughout the project.
outreach.schedule: Initial phases and periodically during project
outreach.indicator: Number of meetings, attendance, awareness metrics
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Public forums will begin during the summer and fall of 2008 to increase awareness of water quality issues with local land owners. ... Periodically during the project, additional meetings may be conducted to help keep interested citizens up-to-date.

outreach.description: Present the project to stakeholder groups and provide ongoing updates.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Periodically, partners will meet with local stakeholder groups (Cattlemen’s Association, Forestry Association, Economic Development agencies, etc.) to introduce this project to members and keep them up-to-date...

outreach.description: Brief local, state, and federal agencies on project results and progress.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: As needed, presentations will be made to local, state and federal agencies to provide project summaries and present results.

outreach.description: Educational workshops for watershed residents (e.g., septic system, clean boating, riparian buffer seminars, forestry, water quality events).
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Workshops will include, but may not be limited to: Septic system maintenance workshops, Clean boating events, Riparian buffer seminars, Forestry planning workshops, Watershed Harmony presentations, Secchi Day, Envirothon, Water quality educational video

outreach.description: Conduct site tours for land owners, partners, and agencies to highlight BMP implementation and project successes.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: As BMP projects are implemented, tours will be given to interested land owners, potential partners and various agencies to increase awareness of project activities and to highlight project successes.

outreach.description: Watershed education events with area schools and organizations for hands-on experience and water quality awareness.
outreach.sourceExcerpt: Partners will work with area schools and organizations to provide hands-on educational events to increase awareness of water quality issues...

geographicAreas.sourceExcerpt: Yellow Creek enters Pickwick Reservoir at TRM 215 near the Tennessee-Mississippi state line. The lower 6 miles of Yellow Creek are impounded by Pickwick Reservoir...

Bear Creek enters Pickwick Reservoir at TRM 225 near the Mississippi-Alabama state line. ... Bear Creek headwaters are located in Franklin and Winston Counties in Alabama. The stream flows west 53 miles through Alabama before entering Mississippi. It then flows north 27 miles through Tishomingo County, Mississippi, before re-entering Alabama.
Indian Creek enters Pickwick Reservoir at TRM 220. Its headwaters drain through the city of Iuka.
